The Act may be cited as the "Our Nation's Trade, Infrastructure, Mobility, and Efficiency Act of 2007" or the "ON TIME Act of 2007". The growth in international trade, particularly containerized trade, is increasing pressure on the nation's transportation network and causing traffic congestion near major US-international gateways. From 2000 to 2005, international trade value and containerized trade shipments significantly rose. Existing and potential future trade agreements indicate a further increase in international trade and freight congestion. Existing and potential future trade agreements suggest a rise in international trade and freight congestion. The United States is part of the World Trade Organization and has 11 free trade agreements with negotiations ongoing with 4 countries and multi-lateral organizations. Traffic congestion in US cities is worsening, leading to wasted hours, extra fuel consumption, and a congestion cost of $78 billion annually. Over 200 freight bottlenecks result in $8 billion in economic losses each year. The transportation system in the US faces significant challenges, with over 200 freight bottlenecks causing $8 billion in economic losses annually. To maintain current conditions, government investments of $235 billion in 2006, $304 billion in 2015, and $472 billion in 2030 are required. To improve conditions for economic productivity, investments of $288 billion in 2006, $368 billion in 2015, and $561 billion in 2030 are needed. To benefit the Nation's economic productivity, government investments of $288 billion in 2006, $368 billion in 2015, and $561 billion in 2030 are necessary. The Act aims to address transportation investment needs in national trade gateway corridors, reduce freight congestion, and enhance the reliability of the freight transportation system. Establishment and collection of national trade gateway corridor fee. Establishment of a national trade gateway corridor fee by the Secretary of Transportation within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The fee is .075 percent of the article's value or $500, whichever is less, for each imported article in commerce. The fee collection process is overseen by the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Transportation will assess and collect a fee for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for the Customs port of unloading of imported articles. The fee collected will be deposited into a specific account and will not apply after fiscal year 2017. Additionally, the Secretary of Transportation will establish an export fee. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a national trade gateway corridor fee on exported articles, equal to .075 percent of the article's value or $500, whichever is less. This fee will not apply after fiscal year 2017. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with Homeland Security and Commerce, will collect a fee for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors. The fee will be .075 percent of the article's value or $500, whichever is less, and will be deposited in a specific account. The fee collected for eligible transportation trade corridor projects will be deposited in the "National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund" account established in the Treasury. The fee will not apply after fiscal year 2017 and will be available for use by the Secretary of Transportation as specified in appropriations Acts. The "National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund" account will consist of deposited amounts for transportation projects. The Secretary of Transportation can use the funds for expenditures until October 1, 2018, to fulfill obligations under the Act. SEC. 4. APPORTIONMENT OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation sets aside 2% of funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund for administrative expenses related to collecting fees on imports and exports. The remaining funds are apportioned to State departments of transportation for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors. The Secretary of Transportation allocates funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund for eligible transportation projects in trade corridors based on fees collected at Customs ports of entry. If a corridor spans multiple states, the funds are divided among the states accordingly. The Secretary of Transportation allocates funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund for eligible transportation projects in trade corridors based on fees collected at Customs ports of entry. If a corridor spans multiple states, the funds are divided among the states based on the total lane miles and vehicle miles traveled on Federal-aid highways in each state. The Secretary of Transportation allocates funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund for eligible transportation projects in trade corridors based on vehicle miles traveled on Federal-aid highways in each state. Amounts granted to a State department of transportation for projects in a transportation trade corridor remain available for obligation for 6 years. The Department of Transportation allocates funds for eligible transportation projects in trade corridors based on vehicle miles traveled on Federal-aid highways. Funds for projects in transportation trade corridors are available for obligation for 6 years and any unobligated amounts after this period are reallocated to other States for similar projects at the Secretary's discretion. SEC. 5. PROJECT SELECTION AND ELIGIBILITY. The Secretary of Transportation must issue project selection guidelines for State departments of transportation to follow in selecting eligible projects for grants under this Act. Guidelines include consulting with various stakeholders and adhering to planning processes outlined in title 23 of the United States Code. The State departments of transportation must adhere to planning processes outlined in title 23 of the United States Code when selecting projects for grants under this Act. They must develop a written selection process, rate proposed projects according to the Act's purposes, and clearly identify the basis for project ratings. The grant program outlined in the Act requires State departments of transportation to follow specific planning processes and criteria for selecting projects. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to State departments of transportation for projects in transportation trade corridors, subject to specific approval and construction standards. Projects on Federal-aid highways must meet federal construction standards, with a federal share of 80% of project costs. The Federal share of the cost for eligible projects under this Act is 80%, and the non-Federal share cannot come from other Federal funds. Prevailing wage rates apply to projects under this section as they would under chapter 1 of title 23, United States Code. SEC. 7. TRANSPORTATION TRADE CORRIDORS. The Secretary of Transportation, with consultation from the Secretary of Commerce, shall establish transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry, with specific criteria for their boundaries and limitations. These corridors may span multiple contiguous states, extend up to 300 miles from the port of entry, and only include areas used for international trade-related motor vehicle and cargo movements. The Secretary of Transportation can establish transportation trade corridors for multiple ports of entry within close proximity. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, proposed corridor boundaries must be published in the Federal Register. A 45-day comment period will follow for public input and hearings on corridor boundaries. The Secretary of Transportation must allow a 45-day comment period for public input on proposed transportation trade corridors. Within one year of the Act's enactment, final corridor boundaries must be published in the Federal Register. Periodic reviews and modifications can be conducted by the Secretary of Transportation before each fiscal year. During the 60-day period before each fiscal year, the Secretary of Transportation may review and modify transportation trade corridors to ensure they align with the objectives of the Act. SEC. 8. REGULATIONS.

The Secretary of Transportation must issue regulations within one year of the Act's enactment to fulfill its objectives.

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund can be appropriated for fiscal years 2009 through 2018, with authorizations becoming available for obligation on October 1 of each fiscal year. Grants approved by the Secretary for highway projects are considered contractual obligations of the Government.

SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines an "eligible project" as a project eligible for assistance under title 23, United States Code, and includes construction or improvements to a publicly owned intermodal freight transfer facility.
